Subject: Re : Bls: Re : [neat] ask about NEAT

Hi,
  Download one of the NEAT implementation (don't ask me which one is th=
e best, it's your choice). Run basic examples, like learning the XOR functi=
on, a often included example of supervised learning. Read the paper that in=
troduce NEAT, not all, but at least the section about how it's done, a one =
hour effort. If you data are vector of fixed size, it's very straighfoward =
to move from the XOR example to your problem.

  But anyway, if the real pr=
oblem is to actually build a classifier and not tinkering with NEAT, better=
 first have a good reason to use NEAT and not something more simple (Occam =
razor principle). A perceptron with backprop, you got plenty of implementat=
ions for it in the most esotheric languages, and it's easy to do your own i=
f you wish to. Same goes for SVM, if you don't use fancy kernels. And both =
are likely to be faster for many supervised learning tasks. I might be corr=
ected by the others, but I think the original purpose of NEAT was to do *UN=
SUPERVISED* learning. Don't expect a less informed algorithm to be better t=
han a better informed one :p

Alex

Judul: Re : [neat] ask about NEAT
















=C2=A0



    =

      
      
      Hi,



NEAT optimize neural network. NEAT will generat=
e many neural network, and you give a *fitness* to each neural network. Hig=
her fitness means more interesting neural network.



Thus, with NEAT, you =
can produce neural networks that can themselves can be used for doing class=
ification. Your fitness for a given neural network should be its classifica=
tion performance. To avoid over-learning (a classifier which does not gener=
alize), be careful to not use the same sample set to compute classification=
 performance.



Also, be sure that more classic machine learning methods a=
re not suitable, like SVM or back-prop, they are likely to be faster if the=
y work good enough on your problem. Those methods are less general than NEA=
T but can exploit some properties specific to supervised learning for speed=
 gain.



Alex
